# Supreme Court announces it will hear challenges to Trump’s tariffs on Nov. 5
![Amy Howe's Headshot](https://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/amy-howe-thumbnail.jpg?w=100&h=100 "Amy Howe")
By[Amy Howe](https://www.scotusblog.com/author/amy-howe/) 
on Sep 18, 2025
[]()[]()[]()[]()[]()
![supremecourt-19](https://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/supremecourt-19-scaled.jpeg)
(Katie Barlow)
The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Nov. 5 in[the pair](https://www.scotusblog.com/cases/case-files/learning-resources-inc-v-trump/)[of challenges](https://www.scotusblog.com/cases/case-files/trump-v-v-o-s-selections/)to President Donald Trump’s authority to impose tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The court on Thursday morning released an[updated calendar](https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_calendars/

# Supreme Court agrees to decide the fate of Trump’s tariffs
![Amy Howe's Headshot](https://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/amy-howe-thumbnail.jpg?w=100&h=100 "Amy Howe")
By[Amy Howe](https://www.scotusblog.com/author/amy-howe/) 
on Sep 9, 2025
[]()[]()[]()[]()[]()
![The U.S. Supreme Court is shown March 17, 2025 in Washington, DC](https://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/GettyImages-2205529616.jpg)
(Win McNamee/Getty Images)
Setting the stage for a major ruling on presidential power, the Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to decide whether a 1977 federal law giving the president certain emergency powers allowed President Donald Trump to levy tariffs on[nearly all goods](https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/09/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-modifies-the-scope-of-reciprocal-tariffs-and-establishes-procedures-for-implementing-trade-deals/)import

President Donald Trump has made tariffs a signature policy of his second term.Chip Somodevilla / Getty Images

Sept. 9, 2025, 4:36 PM EDT / Updated Sept. 9, 2025, 4:45 PM EDT

By [Lawrence Hurley](https://www.nbcnews.com/author/lawrence-hurley-ncpn1298564) and [Steve Kopack](https://www.nbcnews.com/author/steve-kopack-ncpn387336)

WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to quickly decide a high-stakes showdown over [President Donald Trump's tariffs on imports from foreign nations](http://google.com/search?q=nbcnews+tariffs&oq=nbcnews+tariffs&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyCQgAEEUYORiABDIGCAEQIxgnMgYIAhAjGCcyBwgDEAAYgAQyBwgEEC4YgAQyBggFEEUYPDIGCAYQRRg8MgYIBxBFGDzSAQgxODU4ajBqN6gCALACAA&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8), a signature policy of his second term.

# Supreme Court will weigh in on Trump's tariffs. Here's what to know about the case

By
Danielle Kurtzleben

Published September 9, 2025 at 1:43 PM PDT

Key Points

- The Supreme Court on Tuesday granted the Trump administration's request to hear its appeal of lower court rulings invalidating many of President Donald Trump's wide-ranging tariffs.
- The Supreme Court also agreed with the administration's request to consider the appeal on a faster-than-normal timeline.

search_results.title: US Supreme Court to Hear Trump's Tariffs Case on November 5
search_results.text:
# US Supreme Court to Hear Trump's Tariffs Case on November 5

By Reuters

\|

Sept. 18, 2025

By Reuters

\|

Sept. 18, 2025, at 11:23 a.m.

SaveAdd us onComment

_More_

US Supreme Court to Hear Trump's Tariffs Case on November 5

_More_

Reuters

FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks on tariffs in the Rose Garden at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., April 2, 2025. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

(Reuters) - The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday set a date of November 5 for arguments it will hear concerning the legality of Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs in a major test of one of the Republican president's boldest assertions of executive power that has been central to his economic and trade agenda.

The justices announced on September 9 that they would take up the case after a lower court ruled that Trump had overstepped his authority in imposing most of his tariffs under a federal law meant for emergencies.

search_results.title: The Supreme Court Will Settle Trump’s Tariffs. But How?
search_results.text:
Photo: Al Drago/Bloomberg/Getty Images

When it comes to Donald Trump and the law, nothing could be more on point than the recent saga over his tariffs: two losses, no concrete consequences (yet), chaos ahead. The only near certainty is that the Supreme Court will settle this, eventually. When and how they’ll decide is anybody’s guess — though we’ll try, in a moment.

The first ruling came from the Court of International Trade. Don’t be misled by the name: This is not some United Nations–like entity that makes pronouncements but lacks enforcement authority; this is a full-fledged, [constitutionally authorized](https://www.cit.uscourts.gov/about-court), [statutorily created](https://www.fjc.gov/history/courts/u.s.-court-international-trade-1980-present) federal court that specializes in disputes over international trade (“Taxes, Duties, Imposts, and Excises,” as the [Constitution](https://constitution.congress.gov/browse/essay/artI-S8-C1-1-4/ALDE_00013390/#:~:text=Article%20I%2C%20Secti

metadata.title: How will the Supreme Court rule on Trump's tariffs in 2025?
metadata.description:
In 1977, the U.S. Congress enacted the [International Emergency Economic Powers Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Emergency_Economic_Powers_Act) (IEEPA), granting the President certain powers to regulate foreign commerce in the event of a national emergency prompted by an unusual and extraordinary threat emanating from outside the United States.

Upon beginning his second term in office, on January 20, 2025, President Trump declared, [under the IEEPA](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/01/29/2025-02004/designating-cartels-and-other-organizations-as-foreign-terrorist-organizations-and-specially), that threats posed by Mexican drug cartels and other transnational gangs had created a [national emergency](https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/proclamation-10886-declaring-national-emergency-the-southern-border-the-united-states) at America's border with Mexico. Then, on February 1, 2025, President Trump expanded the declared national emergency to cover the influx of drugs across America's border with [Canada](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/02/07/2025-02406/imposing-duties-to-address-the-flow-of-illicit-drugs-across-our-northern-border) as well as [from China](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/02/07/2025-02408/imposing-duties-to-address-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china), and Trump [imposed tariffs](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/02/07/2025-02407/imposing-duties-to-address-the-situation-at-our-southern-border) on all three countries, invoking his authority under the IEEPA.

Subsequently, on April 2, 2025, Trump [declared](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/04/07/2025-06063/regulating-imports-with-a-reciprocal-tariff-to-rectify-trade-practices-that-contribute-to-large-and) that America's trade deficits with the rest of the world constituted another national emergency, and he imposed a policy of "reciprocal tariffs" on the majority of America's trading partners.

These tariffs were soon challenged in court by numerous businesses that import goods into the United States. On May 28, 2025, in *V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. United States*, the [Court of International Trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Court_of_International_Trade) ruled that (1) the reciprocal tariffs exceeded the authority granted to the President under the IEEPA and (2) the trafficking tariffs imposed on Mexico, Canada, and China also violated the IEEPA because the tariffs did not "deal with" the identified threat. The very next day, in *Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump*, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia [ruled](https://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/20250617121437410_No.-___Learning_Resources_Appendix.pdf) that the IEEPA did not authorize the President to impose tariffs in the first place. Though the reasoning differed, both courts agreed that Trump's tariffs were unlawful.

On June 17, 2025, the plaintiffs in *Learning Resources* [asked](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/24/24-1287/363370/20250617121408066_No-___Learning_Resources_Petition_For_A_Writ_Of_Certiorari_Before_Judgment.pdf) the Supreme Court to review the case, arguing that the Court would inevitably rule on the issue and because of its importance should do so without delay. The government [opposed](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/24/24-1287/365424/20250717130752166_24-1287_Learning_Resources_opp_final.pdf), arguing that the Supreme Court should follow the normal appellate process, which would involve letting the Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit review the decision first.

Meanwhile, the *V.O.S. Selections* decision was appealed to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, which, on August 29, 2025, in a 7-4 decision, [affirmed](https://www.cafc.uscourts.gov/opinions-orders/25-1812.OPINION.8-29-2025_2566151.pdf) the determination that the reciprocal and trafficking tariffs exceeded the President's IEEPA authority. (Of the seven judges in the majority, six were appointed by Democrats and one by a Republican. Of the four judges in dissent, two were appointed by Republicans and two by Democrats.)

The government promptly [sought](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/25/25-250/373615/20250903200201802_Trump_v._VOS_petition-final.pdf) Supreme Court review of the *V.O.S. Selections* decision—to which the [plaintiffs](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/25/25-250/373877/20250905154639340_VOS%20-%20Memorandum%20for%20Private%20Respondents.pdf) [acquiesced](https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/25/25-250/374032/20250908160757048_TRUMP%20V.%20VOS%20BRIEF%20FOR%20STATE%20RESPONDENTS%2025%20250.pdf), because of the urgency of the issue—and on September 9, 2025, the Supreme Court [agreed to consolidate and review](https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?filename=/docket/docketfiles/html/public/24-1287.html) both *V.O.S. Selections* and *Learning Resources* on an expedited schedule, with briefing to be filed in September and October and argument to be held in the first week of November 2025. 

`{"format":"metac_reveal_and_close_in_period","info":{"post_id":39893,"question_id":39438}}`
metadata.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve according to the Supreme Court's 2025 ruling on President Trump's reciprocal tariffs and trafficking tariffs in *Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump* and *Trump v.* *V.O.S. Selections, Inc.*

If the Court holds that any challenged tariff measure is lawful and holds none unlawful before January 1, 2026, this question will resolve as **Tariffs lawful**.

If the Supreme Court holds that any challenged tariff measure is unlawful and holds none lawful before January 1, 2026, this question will resolve as **Tariffs unlawful**.

If the Court holds some challenged measures lawful and some unlawful before January 1, 2026, this question will resolve as **Mixed ruling**.

In event of any other ruling before January 1, 2026 in which the Court does not issue a merits holding on legality of any challenged measure (e.g., dismissal as improvidently granted, lack of standing, mootness, GVR, vacate-and-remand without a merits holding, a plurality with no majority judgment on legality) the question will resolve as **Other ruling**.

If the Supreme Court does not render any decision in any of the consolidated cases before January 1, 2026, the question will resolve as **No 2025 ruling**.
